text: On draft at brewery, just as you would expect from a mild. Touch of toast and biscuit, quick dry finish. Very clean. A summer quaffer.
(Tap) hay, bright orange amber colour with a small beige head; aroma of nuts, grain; balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish

Draught at Lost Abbey/ Port Brewing Taproom San Marcos, 23.4.16. 4.8% abv. Clear brown. A little nut and malt and mild chocolate in the nose. Mildly bitter taste with plenty of toastiness. Light body, toasty finish.

Pours dirty brown with small off white head. Aromas and flavor of cinnamon, brown ale, English toast but overall this isnt a classic mild. More of a brown ale with some nuts and light spicing. Still pretty njce

Its been a while since I had a mild and this one is, well, mild. Brown pour with great head and lacing. Some raw barley and a little basement musk. Light clean finish. Creamy consistency. Tap at Sovereign.

On tap at the Confessional. Light brown pour with an off white head. Mild roasted malt bouquet. Taste follows suit. Thinner body but really easy drinking. Hints of bitter chocolate and expresso. Easy drinking.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2015 Tasted on tap in a shaker glass at ElijahPs in Alton, Il. It poured a near-opaque brown colour with sudsy beige foam, long-lasting with a little lace. Aroma was low but pleasant, flavours matched and were much bigger: super malty, bready, biscuity, chocolatey, hint of bright coffee acidity, tannin-y like nuts or strong black tea. Non-deScript hops which provided a balanced bitterness, but little else. Light-medium body, moderate carbonation, nice alcoholic strength, dark malt complexity lasts well into the aftertaste. Reminiscent of The Civil Life American Brown except less hoppy. Lost Abbey Red Poppy is one of my all-time favourite beers, and English mild is my all-time favourite style, so Ive been hoping to taste this base beer for years, ever since learning of the connection. What a treat, AND its as delicious as Id hoped, which is not always the case with these long-term obsessions. Its easy to see how it holds up so well to tart cherries and hardwood aging.
Brown. Nutty. Delicious. Chocolate. Pudding like, its silky and muddy at the same time.

On tap at Elijah Ps - Pours tawny brown with an off-white head. The aroma is nutty, toasty, rich, smooth and a little creamy. It has a medium / light body that is crisp and has mild sharp carbonation. The flavor starts with dry nutty malt, toast, woody/paper, light spice and some astringency. The finish is a bit richer and nuttier with some light spice. Nice sessionable beer.

Draft at The Confessional. Poured a hazy copper color with a small off-white head. Aroma was mostly toasted malts, sweet dark malt notes. Nutty notes too. Flavor was nice nutty notes, real easy to drink. Enjoyable.

Pint at Elijah Ps. Dark brown and nice looking. Can that ABV be correct? This was bold for a mild. Coffee, nuts, and chocolate flavors. The body is smooth and rich. Just a bit of darker fruit and citrus. This one is a winner! Huge kudos for brewing such a beer with that low alcohol volume.

Draft at the brewery. Pours hazy copper with a dizzy beige head and lots of lacing. Tastes like toasted malt, nutty, burnt toast. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like toast, burnt roasted malt, nutty.

Tap at the brewery. Pours clear brown with a medium, frothy beige head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is toast and grain malt, light nutty malt notes and earthy hops. Flavor is sweet malt dominant, light earthy hops and bitterness with a sweet finish. Light body and medium carbonation.
tap: never would have made the connection to Red Poppy on my own. Decent English brown...roast and caramel. Easy drinking, medium bodied with a roasted malt lightly bitter finish.

18th March 2014: on-tap in the Hopping Pig, San Diego. The best beer on my first flight of four. Came a clear reddy/brown dark amber with a full beige crown. Malt notes fill your nose and mouth with chocolate being the strongest noticeable, caramel and toffee follow closely behind. This isnt a sweet brew though, it is balanced with a fruity, piney hop undertone that stops the malts running away with the brew. Tasty and unexpected in San Diego, glad I came across it.

Amberish brown in color... Aroma of brown, caramel malts... Flavor is light brown, nutty malts, light body... Not terribly complex but fairly sessionable... Decent

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draught at the brewpub in San Marcos. Clear deep amber beer with a nice offwhite/beige head. Malty chocolate aroma, caramel, toffee, fruity, roasted, cocoa and licorice. Malty fruity caramel flavor, grassy, chocolate, some fruity hops.

On tap in San Diego (CA)

$3.00 for a world class mild ale that serves as the base for a beer I have been dying to try for years? People in San Diego truly are spoiled when it comes to choice. A mild ale that would put almost any in England to shame this has a little bit of a West Coast attitude as well.

Aroma / Appearance - A chestnut base is as rich as the inside of a peanut butter Buckeye. Absorbing all light, it is paired with a pleasing dusty head. Nuttiness lingers in the air with the smell of gentle hops that bind together the aspects of everything a mild ale should be.

Flavor / Palate - The feel of fresh summer iced tea hits the tongue with a refreshing presence. It is tough not to just drink the entire thing in a few sips and order another. The creamy mouthfeel progresses towards a mild bitter conclusion rich in flavor while still delicate enough to be sessionable. If this is the base for Red Poppy I can not wait to crack open a bottle.
At The Lost Abbey on draft. You may not know this, but this beer is the base of Red a Poppy. This is a true mild that has a nice malty sour kick.

Tap at Lost Abbey. Clear cola brown. Medium tan head. Nose is nice rye bread, thick grain, a bit olive and vegetal nose. Taste is cola, thin, suddy, mild whole wheat pizza crust. Soapy, suddy mouthfeel. Okay.

On tap at The Lost Abbey. Pours dark brown with a creamy off white head. Aroma of malt, some toasted notes, red fruits and caramel. Flavor is sweet and malty with some caramel, hay, red fruits and toasted grains. Medium to thon body, soft carbonation.

Draught @ Port Brewing/Lost Abbey, San Marcos, CAPours clear dark amber with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, dried fruits and hint of chocolate. Taste is light to medium sweet and light bitter with a long caramel finish. Body is medium, texture is thin to oily, carbonation is soft.

On tap at the brewpub. A clear, brown beer with a small off-white head. Lightly roasted aroma, nuts, some caramel and a little hoppy touch in the aroma. Its quite dry on the palate, with a nice carbonation and flavors of roasted malts and some coffee. A lightly piney, bitter touch in the back. A bit short finish. Too boring for me. 130815

Pours reddish brown with low light tan head. Aroma of hay, caramel, light cherry. Taste is mild and sweet chocolate. Light lingering chocolate finish. Body is light and slick with average carbonation.
Draft at the brewery. Clear reddish brown color. Aroma of caramel covered chocolate. Overall good.

Brown in color with a khaki head. Nose is somewhat sweet and nutty. Decent toast and cocoa aromas, some roast, toffee, and a light earthiness. Hints of fruit esters, too. The flavor is okay. Some roasted malt, toast, bread, and light toffee sweetness. Mild coffee, chocolate, and very light fruit notes. A bit of earthy hop flavor and bitterness.

Its alright

Brown pour with thin head. Mild easy to drink. Faint nose. Nutty notes, light body. Inoffensive but nothing to write home about.
Sampled at the brewery...i thought it was pretty decent.  Nice roasty nutty flavor that lingers and has a good bit of hop.  More refreshing that I would have guessed, nice overall balance.

A clear dark brown colored beer, with a beige head. The aroma of dark roasted malt with fruits and a little hop. The taste of dark fruits, some roasted malt and notes of hop. The aftertaste is some sweet with bitter notes.

Draught at Port Brewing/Lost Abbey. Hazy, deep chestnut/brown liquid with medium off-white head. Aroma of biscuit, earth, dark chocolate, smoke and light caramel. Taste is dry and light bitter with notes of biscuit, caramel and earth. Medium bodied with medium carbonation.

Draft with Linh at the brewery. Pours a deep reddish brown body with nice town lacing. Aroma is sweet malts, light fruit and nuts. Mouthfeel is light and creamy with notes of fruity malts, light brown sugar and nut.

Lightly hazy dark brown color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of caramel malts, some toast, and also burnt notes. Taste of caramel malts, toffee, toast, and lightly dry / yeasty.

Draught; served as  Dawn Patrol Dark Mild  Small light-brown head over dark cola-coloured beer. Chocolate, chocolatemalt, pine pulp, cacaopowder; very layered-complex nose for such a low ABV beer. Sweet, milkchocolate, touch of alcohol (!?), less complex than the nose. Maybe a bit young sample. Medium bodied, slick to a bit oily, maybe again the youngness. Good mild, excellent nose.

Draught at the brewery. Nice Enlgish brown with a toasty, lightly chocolatey malt flavor, modest hops, dry finish, and very high drinkability. Just a nicely sessionable and malt-focused ale. I was surprised at the dark malt flavor present, considering that this is the base for Red Poppy. Good pint.

On tap at the brewery for a taste of this base beer. Light brown in color with some tan head. Light to medium bodied beer. Flavors are simple with roasted malt and just a touch of background hops. Not bad and seems like a good neutral profile for a base.
Draft at the brewery.  Clear brown pour, slight red tinge.  Light tan head.  Sweet malts, nuts, and a bit of caramel and light hops.  Not bad for a brown, but still boring.
Co-rate!  Draft at the brewery. Clear reddish brown color. Aroma of caramel covered chocolate. Taste has slight nuttiness and caramel malt. Decent.
Draft at the brewery.  Clear reddish brown color.  Aroma of caramel covered chocolate.  Taste has slight nuttiness and caramel malt.  Decent.
